key_insight: Spatia preserves a persistent 3D scene point cloud as spatial memory and uses it to iteratively generate and update video clips via visual SLAM, enabling much stronger long-term spatial and temporal consistency in generated videos.
problem_solved: Existing video generation models struggle to maintain coherent scene geometry and temporal continuity over long sequences because video signals are dense and high-dimensional.
method: Maintain an explicit 3D scene point cloud as persistent spatial memory that represents static scene geometry.
Iteratively generate short video clips conditioned on the spatial memory, then update the memory continuously using visual SLAM.
Employ a dynamic–static disentanglement design to separate moving content from persistent scene structure, stabilizing long-range consistency.
impact: Provides a scalable way to generate longer, more geometrically and temporally consistent videos, useful for applications requiring persistent scene understanding (e.g., simulation, AR/VR, robotics) and for practitioners building infrastructure for generative video systems.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: 3D point-cloud memory → clip generator → visual SLAM updater (loop) to show iterative generate+update flow.
3D scene point-cloud visualization annotated as 'persistent spatial memory' vs per-frame pixels.
Before/after frame sequences showing improved long-term consistency (e.g., stable background, coherent object positions).
Illustration of dynamic–static disentanglement: overlayed masks or color-coding separating moving objects from static scene geometry.
paper_title: Spatia: Video Generation with Updatable Spatial Memory
paper_authors: Jinjing Zhao, Fangyun Wei, Zhening Liu, Hongyang Zhang, Chang Xu
